data.title: Great tour, but a TERRIBLE Map
data.text: We parked at Pack Square.  Street meter parking to commence the Urban Trail.  Visited the Visitor Center for a map and a pocket full of quarters to feed the parking meters.  The map was so confusing that we eventually used our car to find "locations" identified on the tour.  It was Veterans Day so some of the sites, (Thomas Wolfe Home) were closed.

data.title: Different
data.text: We done this over the summer and enjoyed walking around trying to find the statues.  We could not find a map to show us where they were since this was a spur of the moment trip.  Asheville is a fun place but I am amazed at the number of homeless on the streets looking for money.

data.title: Loved the hunt for sculptures
data.text:
I love sculptures (not statues) in public spaces, so the urban trail in Asheville was a perfect fit for me.  The scavenger hunt made it fun and interesting, even though I did not find all 30 sculptures.  Among my favorites were "Crossroads" (pigs and turkeys being taken to southern markets from Tennessee), "Flat Iron Architecture" (a giant flat iron reflecting the nearby Flat Iron Building) and "Past and Promise" (little girl drinking at a horsehead fountain).  If you want to learn something about Asheville while getting your exercise, this activity is for you.  Best of all, it's free!

The trail does require a good amount of walking (1.7 miles) with some uphill climbs, but is not strenuous.  You can always take a break if needed.  I would recommend 2-3 hours for this activity.

data.title: What a great way to see the city and learn about its history!
data.text:
Read about this in the AAA Tourbook and got our map from the downtown Visitors' Center where we were right across from some of the sites.  It is a self-guided 1.7 mile walking tour of 30 downtown Asheville sites.  The locations are numbered and as part of a public arts program there are brass plaques which tell the history and there is often some sort of art like a top hat, a cart, tools, etc. at the site and that art is representative of that location and its history.  The walk is pleasant, some hills, but a great way to learn about buildings that you would have just walked past and now known anything about.Since it is self-paced, you can stop along the way, get a snack,
take photos and just get a feel for this neat city.

data.title: Downtown Asheville walk
data.text: Nice walk in downtown Asheville. Art gallery is a nice place to visit. Shoppers will find the place interesting.

data.title: Pleasant Self-Guided Walking Tour
data.text: We actually saw the art before realizing it was part of a public art trail. We picked up a brochure and map and were happy to make our way around Asheville admiring art and learning a bit about the city's history. The trail is broken up into several categories/periods (Frontier Period, Gilded Age, Times of Thomas Wolfe, Era of Civic Pride and Age of Diversity). Although one can begin the trail anywhere, we started at Pack Square. We spent several hours walking this Urban Trail, but we also stopped several times to eat and admire other aspects of the city. Finding the art, which can sometimes be somewhat hidden, is part of the experience. A great way to introduce a person to Asheville. Fun for both kids and adults.

data.title: Walk through Downtown Asheville
data.text: The Urban Trail was a little disappointing, although it is nice to have a self-guided walking tour through the city. I thought there would be more sculptures, but it's mostly plaques in the sidewalk. We ended up not doing the entire course, so I can't speak to the entire walk.

data.title: Worth the Walk!
data.text: Stop by the Visitor's Center and pick up a map for the Urban Trail.  It is an excellent resource for your self-guided tour.  The sculptures and plaques throughout the city are a delight to discover and the descriptive guide gives you insight to their meaning.  The trail is supposed to give you an overview of the development of the city over time--but that isn't quite so obvious. Still, it is impressive, free and well worth your 1-2 hours.

data.title: Fun sculptures!
data.text: We just happened upon these works of art while wandering around downtown Asheville. I didn't know there was a name for these sculptures!  The cat walk was a different way to display art. They had one stretching on the ground, one on top of a short wall & another up a light pole.  The little girl at the drinking fountain was my favorite.

data.title: Liked the Flat Iron
data.text:
These sculptures are spread out throughout Asheville.  It took a bit of online searching but I was able to find a map of their locations before we went.

It was just too hot & humid for us to walk to them all.  But my favorite was the Flat Iron!

data.title: Great way to keep kid involved
data.text: Walking around the city can get boring for kid something but the cit has come up with a map and different items around the city which made it fun for our kids. It was like kids were searching the city while the adults were enjoying the sites.

data.title: Learning Asheville
data.text: I've now done this self- guided tour twice with different family members.  Very nice low- key way to learn about Asheville while stumbling upon local businesses.

data.title: Must for Architecture and History Fans
data.text: I had a 1.5 hour stop in Asheville. Instead of stopping at a roadside rest area, I pulled up an urban trail map online and practically ran through the town. Even had lunch at a great restaurant on the trail.

data.title: Great way to get a picture of downtown Asheville!
data.text: We're in our 70s, but the walk of probably 1 1/2 to 2 miles wasn't tough.  It takes a meandering and roughly circular walk through downtown Asheville.  It was definitely up-and-down-hill, but not exceedingly so, as long as we didn't push for speed.  There were enough stops to read the mapped bronze plaques and look at the buildings that the pace was leisurely.  It was over more quickly than we expected.

data.title: Engaging
data.text: Some things were tough to find but overall we got most of them.  It took us by neat shops to stop in to as well.

data.title: Interesting history walk
data.text: This is a self-guided walk through downtown Asheville, which includes statues and plaques that describe the history of town and events that happened here.

data.title: Walking around the city
data.text: This is a nice walking 'trail' which winds around the city with sculptures and wall art that shows the history of the town. Very interesting even though we weren't able to do it all due to a heavy downpour.

data.title: Fun and Interesting
data.text: We enjoyed finding the plaques and decorative art along this historic trail. In the process I learned a lot about Asheville past and present. For example why are there double wooden doors on buildings in the old market district? The trail is a good work out.

data.title: Interesting and an easy walk, wheelchair accessible.
data.text: This is a great walk for couples, families, all ages.  We found it really opens up the city to us, we found a lot of places we didn't know about.

data.title: Nice
data.text: The weather was great so we really enjoyed the statues. The sidewalks were wide enough. We saw lots of beautiful flowers also.
